title: Mid Level Analyst; Lead Trainer
description: • Responsible for conducting comprehensive all-source analysis, research and fusion of biographic and biometric information on individuals of interest • Conducted research, multi-int fusion analysis, and exploitation of biometric and forensic derived intelligence • Provided I2 to DIA in support of worldwide operations • Prepare all-source I2 products and assessments for publication to support government requirements and disseminate the information to the intelligence community • Published over 400 biometric intelligence assessment reports on individuals targeted during biometric enrollment • Personally performed 20% of intelligence production for a team of 15 individuals • Appointed as one of three review and approval authorities for all assessment production of the team • Identified nefarious individuals based upon detailed analysis of forensically derived information and coordinated with national agencies to ensure individuals’ inclusion on Department of Defense (DoD) Biometric Enabled Watchlist (BEWL) • Lead trainer for new analysts on the team, promoted to lead trainer for the entire program • Manage the DNA related analysis team; to include briefings with JFAIDD (AFDIL database), FBI, and GFCX (EFDIS database) • Prime liaison between the UKDEF and analysts

title: Program Manager
description: I manage the integration of geography, language, demographics and other relevant structured and unstructured content with GSI's native linguists, cultural analysts, developers and GIS disciplines for the collection and conflation of authoritative data into highly usable Human Geography content. GSI's authoritative content resides in relational geodatabases, supporting the geospatial representation of societal hierarchy networks, religious affiliations, leadership and levels of influence, providing geospatially accurate foundation content for visualization, enriched analytics, and informed decision-making. GSI's authoritative Human Geography foundation data enables users to support high cognitive analyst requirements, an understanding of the nature of "place", Patterns of Life, and understanding not only the "Where" but also the "Who" for current and anticipatory analytics.

title: Federal Business Development Manager
description: As the Federal Business Development Manager, I managed major initiatives and awards supporting the National System for Geospatial-Intelligence (NSG) and Federal Programs. I developed strategic goals and relationships with respect to emerging customer needs, competitive positioning, requisite capabilities, and the tactical moves necessary to enable Fugro to capture opportunity in the market. Many of the programs required airborne EO, LiDAR, IfSAR and other remotely sensed phenomenology, with knowledge generated by the analysis, and exploitation of content, and derived products, and solutions to support on-shore (terrestrial), off-shore (maritime) and littoral (nearshore) requirements supported by Fugro's global capabilities. I identified and targeted leads, built customer and strategic industry relationships, while qualifying, researching, and developing business opportunities. I researched the internal and external environment in which Fugro, competitors and potential/existing clients operated, while building and maintaining a broad network of colleagues, partners and customers to share information and obtain prospects. I directed specific proposal activities, and participated in trades shows and conferences to sustain industry and client awareness of Fugro corporate services and capabilities. As the NGA Account Manager, I collaborated with colleagues on internal programs, coordinated and proactively maintained communications with the customer, participated in negotiation of contracts and contract changes, and served as liaison among project management and planning, project team, and line management, briefing NGA and Fugro Senior Management as required for capabilities, programs and target acquisitions.

title: Program Manager & Site Manager
description: I managed a major geospatial-intelligence contract, with multiple task orders ranging from $100k - $27M, exhibiting operational execution excellence completing largest single Orthoimagery mapping task order of continental United States borders in 2009. Currently direct Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) and Orthoimagery programs, and Support Services which includes all IT, Database, Source, Development, Training, and Mission Assurance activities within Department. Demonstrated exceptional interpersonal and professional skills in successfully leading seamless and complete organizational, functional, and facility transition prompted by purchase of 3001 Inc. by Northrop Grumman in 2009 - 10. Concurrently led numerous process improvements and accelerated integrated technology insertions to produce production efficiencies. Leadership and management skills promoted growth of programs through enhanced efficiency, improved quality and client satisfaction, while enhancing professional opportunities for employees, and building revenue and profitability for organization. Meet regularly with government clients to communicate program status and to continue to improve company capabilities to meet client needs.

title: Vice President
description: Vice President of 3001, Inc. Intel-Defense Solutions (IDS) Division. As VP I managed all NGA programs and realized significant revenue growth exceeding targets, while relocating and expanding the main production office from Stennis Space Center, MS to Slidell, LA, and growing production offices in St. Louis, MO, Gainesville, FL, and Huntsville, AL. I worked with the Louisiana Economic Business Development Council to leverage state and Parrish economic stimulus incentives to further achieve business advantages for 3001 IDS operations,and overall company financial strength. I facilitated and collaborated the management and business transition of 3001, Inc. sale to Northrop Grumman in 2008 - 2009.

title: Physical Scientist
description: Provided technical, administrative, fiscal and research support to the Chairman, managed laboratories, equipment and personnel for at-sea operations, coordinated staff assignments, prepared fiscal and out-year Department and marine operations budgets, and supervised support staff, space, equipment and ship requirements. Served as department liaison with Oceanographer of the Navy (OP-096), successfully lobbying for continued ship operation funding, as well as NPS liaison to University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS), and other government, state, and private agencies, laboratories, and educational and research activities, for the exchange of information and technical assistance. With science grant funding, planned and executed acquisition of Philippine Mindanao current data (P-3 sonobuoy deployment) for student theses and data presentation at a national symposium. Supported field research surveying and photogrammetric analysis of coastal erosion in California. Received NPS Science and Engineering Outstanding Employee Award in 1989.

title: Cartographer and Program Manager
description: Cartographer job series included positions of Photogrammetrist, Bathymetrist, Congressional Liaison, and Navigation Program Manager. Performed multiple functions in research, compilation, evaluation, all source analysis, and production of nautical charts and navigation products. On cruise deployments, performed hydrographic, bathymetric and navigation data acquisition, including development of gray scale algorithms for shallow water navigation hazards using first order LANDSAT imagery, and Global Positioning System accuracy analysis comparison with legacy electronic navigation systems. As Congressional Liaison, developed knowledge of Agency products and capabilities to support congressional requirements. As Program Manager, generated annual Program Objective Memorandum (POM), and performed program management of the Navigation Publication program, which produced Congressionally mandated Safety of Navigation publications annually in support of Department of Defense and maritime requirements.

summary: A decisive and energetic analyst with deep cultural, political, economic, and security expertise in the Middle East. Results driven researcher with collection, processing, integration, analysis, evaluation, and interpretation experience. An individual that brings a unique combination of regional experience, strong technical skills, flexibility and adaptability. ★ Information Collection & Evaluation ★ Collect and articulate information from a wide variety of actionable all-source products. Distinguish between useful and superfluous information through evaluating priority requirements. Evaluate information for relevancy and applicability to customer’s needs, whether it involves political, economic, or security concerns. ★ Analysis & Production ★ Break complex information into smaller, understandable pieces relevant to subject matter. Utilize a variety of analytic and presentation tools including network analysis (Gephi 0.8), link analysis, cartographic and spatial analysis (ArcGIS 10.0), inductive and deductive reasoning, and brainstorming with colleagues. ★ Dissemination & Presentation ★ Produce actionable high-quality reports and briefings based on synthesis of information with a high level of confidence that can be disseminated to clients. Present analyses in either written or verbal forms that reflect timeliness, intelligence and applicability of product. ★ Cultural & Regional Expertise ★ Well versed with current political, social, and economic frameworks in the GCC, Iraq, and Kurdish regions. First-hand knowledge of Saudi Arabian and Iraqi domestic policies and risks arising from succession, sectarian influences, and terrorism. Lived in Saudi Arabia for over three years, and traveled to various Middle Eastern countries, such as Kuwait, the U.A.E., Bahrain, Lebanon, and Oman.

title: Field Representative
description: Maintain work assignments to meet various Nielsen objectives and performance goals including Market and Sample commitments, contractual requirements, quality standards, policy and procedural requirements, and customer satisfaction. Perform site surveys to collect detailed information on the consumer devices in a household. Demonstrate aptitude using various in-house software systems, exhibit superior customer service and communication skills, and maintain detailed field reports.

summary: A decisive and energetic analyst with deep cultural, political, economic, and security expertise in the Middle East. Results driven researcher with collection, processing, integration, analysis, evaluation, and interpretation experience. An individual that brings a unique combination of regional experience, strong technical skills, flexibility and adaptability. ★ Information Collection & Evaluation ★ Collect and articulate information from a wide variety of actionable all-source products. Distinguish between useful and superfluous information through evaluating priority requirements. Evaluate information for relevancy and applicability to customer’s needs, whether it involves political, economic, or security concerns. ★ Analysis & Production ★ Break complex information into smaller, understandable pieces relevant to subject matter. Utilize a variety of analytic and presentation tools including network analysis (Gephi 0.8), link analysis, cartographic and spatial analysis (ArcGIS 10.0), inductive and deductive reasoning, and brainstorming with colleagues. ★ Dissemination & Presentation ★ Produce actionable high-quality reports and briefings based on synthesis of information with a high level of confidence that can be disseminated to clients. Present analyses in either written or verbal forms that reflect timeliness, intelligence and applicability of product. ★ Cultural & Regional Expertise ★ Well versed with current political, social, and economic frameworks in the GCC, Iraq, and Kurdish regions. First-hand knowledge of Saudi Arabian and Iraqi domestic policies and risks arising from succession, sectarian influences, and terrorism. Lived in Saudi Arabia for over three years, and traveled to various Middle Eastern countries, such as Kuwait, the U.A.E., Bahrain, Lebanon, and Oman.

title: English Language Instructor
description: Supported the Saudi Arabian government’s Technical and Vocational Training Corporation’s (TVTC) English Language Program by educating male college graduates to be productive participants in the national workforce through an intensive English language program. Developed and implemented concentrated listening, speaking, reading, and writing EFL instruction. Generated creative lesson plans to integrate EFL skills around relevant vocational themes and topics, such as accounting, electronics, business, and information technology, to ease student’s transition into the national and international workforce. Led and conducted structured teacher training and seminars related to use of technologies; completed a teacher’s training manual that was disseminated throughout the country. Experienced in advanced instructional methodology such as experiential learning, constructivism, project and inquiry based learning, and student-centered learning. Worked closely with Site Director and Department Head to develop curriculum materials to meet the specific English language needs of TVTC students. Displayed ability to prioritize and multi-task under strict deadlines in a foreign environment. Logged over 3,500 hours of in-class lecture time in a collegiate environment.

title: Government Relations Intern
company: Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) Mission to the United States of America
description: Conducted analytic research and wrote detailed reports of high-profile briefings and conferences regarding important issues that were presented to high-level decision makers at the PLO Mission. Edited manuals and legal documents (visa instructions, power of attorney, etc.) that were translated from Arabic to English to ensure grammatical and informational accuracy. Scanned and reviewed Arabic news publications, social networks, and other online and print sources for important information regarding the Middle East and Palestinian governmental interests. Attended U.S.-Arab related events and briefings on Capitol Hill, the Center for Strategic International Studies (CSIS), the Brookings Institute, Saudi ARAMCO, Conoco Phillips, Johns Hopkins University, and various embassies in Washington, D.C. Met personally with various high-level actors in Palestinian and Arab governments, including members of the Palestinian Negotiations Affairs Department (NAD), office of President Mahmoud Abbas, and officials from the Arab League.

title: Program Intern
description: Participated in an 11-week seminar series at the George Washington University: Elliot School of International Affairs. The seminars included lectures on matters facing the Middle East, such as conflict, socioeconomic impacts, and the various cultures and religions present in the region. The series also covered subjects in intelligence and business analysis, and further provided a forum for participants to ask questions, meet with professionals, etc. Additionally, the internship involved weekly meetings with various companies, non-profits, governmental agencies, and Middle Eastern embassies.

summary: A decisive and energetic analyst with deep cultural, political, economic, and security expertise in the Middle East. Results driven researcher with collection, processing, integration, analysis, evaluation, and interpretation experience. An individual that brings a unique combination of regional experience, strong technical skills, flexibility and adaptability. ★ Information Collection & Evaluation ★ Collect and articulate information from a wide variety of actionable all-source products. Distinguish between useful and superfluous information through evaluating priority requirements. Evaluate information for relevancy and applicability to customer’s needs, whether it involves political, economic, or security concerns. ★ Analysis & Production ★ Break complex information into smaller, understandable pieces relevant to subject matter. Utilize a variety of analytic and presentation tools including network analysis (Gephi 0.8), link analysis, cartographic and spatial analysis (ArcGIS 10.0), inductive and deductive reasoning, and brainstorming with colleagues. ★ Dissemination & Presentation ★ Produce actionable high-quality reports and briefings based on synthesis of information with a high level of confidence that can be disseminated to clients. Present analyses in either written or verbal forms that reflect timeliness, intelligence and applicability of product. ★ Cultural & Regional Expertise ★ Well versed with current political, social, and economic frameworks in the GCC, Iraq, and Kurdish regions. First-hand knowledge of Saudi Arabian and Iraqi domestic policies and risks arising from succession, sectarian influences, and terrorism. Lived in Saudi Arabia for over three years, and traveled to various Middle Eastern countries, such as Kuwait, the U.A.E., Bahrain, Lebanon, and Oman.

title: Chief of Research
description: Supervises approximately 12 faculty and research staff to conduct research in national security and international relations for the leadership of the U.S. Air Force and the Department of Defense. Manages the contract research budget for Air University -- a Level V doctoral degree-granting university specializing in national security, public policy and international relations. Acts, as needed, as adjunct professor at the Air War College, Air Command and Staff College and Squadron Officer College. Briefly served as interim Deputy Director and Dean during transition period between directors and key personnal in 2012-2013.

summary: Strategic Planning at any organizational level. Published author on long-range strategic planning. Able to lead organizations on a path of self-discovery as to how the future will change its ability to function in the years ahead. Television Weather Anchor/Meteorologist. Achieved overall Nielsen and Arbitron ratings in the upper 30s with share ratings in the low 50s as Chief Meteorologist for WISC-TV -- top 100 market. Pioneered use of on-air picture in teleprompter enabling meteorologists to appear more comfortable on-camera. Military analyst. Proficient in all econometric means of analysis and my directorship of research centers has brought me into contact with virtually every system DOD uses today. 27 years of experience analyzing and developing concepts of operations across four continents provides me the background to offer analytical commentary or advice on the implications and outcomes of impending military operations. Specialties: Leadership, Strategic Planning, Meterology, Political Science, Teaching, Lecturing, Analytical or Applied Research

title: Director, AF Center for Strategy and Technology
description: Directs U.S. Air Force's principle long-rang planning research organization charged with investigating the national and strategic implications of new and emerging technologies. Prepares and presents annual reports for the Air Force senior leadership recommending actions to ensure the Air Force remains effective regardless of future technical trends. Served as a faculty member at the Air War College. Lectured and conducted graduate seminars in strategic and international security studies.

summary: Strategic Planning at any organizational level. Published author on long-range strategic planning. Able to lead organizations on a path of self-discovery as to how the future will change its ability to function in the years ahead. Television Weather Anchor/Meteorologist. title: Colonel (retired)
description: Served for over 28 years on active duty as flight instructor in F-111 aircraft; chief administrator for several organizations up to 4000 persons in size; Chief, Leadership Branch for the Air Force's primary leadership school for all members of its officer corps; Chief of Strategic Planning for all Air Force Special Forces, managing a $9 billion modernization portfolio. Held numerous supervisory and leadership positions within fighter and special operations as well as in the Air Force's university system. Served as a flight instructor in the T-37, T-43, and F-111 aircraft and have logged combat time in the AC-130 gunship. I have lectured and taught seminars, both at the undergraduate and gratudate levels at the Senior Non-Commissioned Officer Academy, the Squadron Officer College, Air Command and Staff College, and the Air War College.

title: Air Force Institute of Technology Liaison; Associate Professor, Aerospace Studies
description: Supervised all officers attending Air Force-directed Education at the UW. Discovered and resolved housing and medical benefits issues that had been left to atrophy for 10 years, putting all junior personnel below the poverty line and without access to health care. Fixed both in 18 months; moved our non-commissioned officers out of the housing projects, and ensured they were paid wages above the poverty line. Completed PhD in Political Science in 2 years 9 months, breaking the departmental record. Studied all analytical methods to include basic and advanced statistics, maximum likelihood, qualitative methods, fuzzy set logic, and auto-regressive integrated moving-average time-series modeling. Analytically trainind in all tools.

summary: Darrik is an Anthropology student at Brigham Young University. Darrik has always been passionate about the intricacies and dynamics of all kinds of people, and found the academic application of this passion studying Socio-Cultural Anthropology. He volunteered as a missionary for the LDS church in Arizona, and thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to work with and learn from all sorts of people in all types of areas, especially the Native American people of central Arizona. Darrik has conducted field research in India, and had the opportunity to backpack the entire country for one month. After spending time with the cobblers of the streets of India, Darrik has been enamored with leather work and loves to make moccasins. Darrik is an avid Rock 'N' Roll connoisseur and historian, and plays guitar in a local band. Darrik is a personable and innovate seeker of a position in branding, marketing, social innovation, micro-finance, and development.

summary: Darrik is an Anthropology student at Brigham Young University. Darrik has always been passionate about the intricacies and dynamics of all kinds of people, and found the academic application of this passion studying Socio-Cultural Anthropology. He volunteered as a missionary for the LDS church in Arizona, and thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to work with and learn from all sorts of people in all types of areas, especially the Native American people of central Arizona. Darrik has conducted field research in India, and had the opportunity to backpack the entire country for one month. After spending time with the cobblers of the streets of India, Darrik has been enamored with leather work and loves to make moccasins. Darrik is an avid Rock 'N' Roll connoisseur and historian, and plays guitar in a local band. Darrik is a personable and innovate seeker of a position in branding, marketing, social innovation, micro-finance, and development.

title: Researcher, Student, Resident Assistant
company: Brigham Young University Indian Field School
description: Spent a semester abroad in India studying caste and culture-specific small businesses. Developed structure of research projects including planning and scheduling interviews, and creatively guiding interviews to elicit relevant data. Presented research proposals and findings to academic board of Andhra University. • Acted as resident assistant, providing leadership for Brigham Young University students attending the program. • Traveled extensively throughout India including Amritsar, Calcutta, Delhi, Jaipur and Chennai. Worked with students from a wide variety of locations and backgrounds including Ethiopia and Iran.

summary: EDUCATION: Political science - PhD in Government from Georgetown Univ. (comparative politics, empirical field research in Germany) EXPERIENCE HILITES: Senior Operations Research Analyst supporting Domestic Nuclear Detection Office (DNDO). Homeland Security: Sr. Ops Research Analyst in support of Domestic Nuclear Detection Office (independent contractor to TASC). Advisor on homeland security and "The Americas" to Defense Threat Reduction Agency (Northrop Grumman, TASC). CISSP (Certified Information Systems Security Professional) - Info assurance/computer security policy & assessments for DOD (SAIC) ORSA (operations research systems analysis): Computer simulation modeling (TACSIM Program, US Army) plus project leadership/system engineering for major combat/Information Warfare model (US Army Studies & Analysis Activity) Political-military studies (US Army Concepts Analysis Agency) (CSIS - Ctr for Strategic and Int'l Studies thinktank) Military tactical/strategic intelligence collection planning, analysis/estimates, incl imagery interpretation/photogrammetry (U.S. Army) SPECIALTIES: Homeland security; Information assurance, special attn to risk management and COOP/DR - Continuity of Ops/disaster recovery; Political-military studies; Intelligence analysis/estimates System engineering project management

title: Senior Operations Research Analyst
description: Senior Operations Research Analyst, supporting Domestic Nuclear Detection Office, Dept. of Homeland Security On contract to I3PG (Gettysburg, PA), a subcontractor to TASC, Inc. Support mission to detect and prevent the entry of radiological and nuclear materials and devices into US territories. Conduct research and analysis of situation, threat, policy, operations, methods, technology. Assess mission and resources to identify required capabilities and capability gaps, identify and evaluate candidate solutions, develop capability development concepts and plans. Develop system engineering documents such as mission needs statement, concept of operations, development plan, cost estimates, cost-effectiveness analysis of alternative solutions, study plans, etc. Perform qualitative and quantitative analysis and assessments using appropriate methods and tools. Wrote “Mission Needs Statement for Global Nuclear Detection Architecture Mission-Critical Messaging (MCM),” and follow-on concepts and planning documents. Developed items for field test of Long Range Radiation Detection systems.

title: Advisor on homeland security to Defense Threat Reduction Agency
description: Assisted coordination of DTRA support to combatant commands (NORTHCOM, SOUTHCOM), Dept of Defense agencies, and other members of the homeland security (HS) and Combating Weapons of Mass Destruction (CWMD) communities. Researched and analyzed threat, detect, prevent, protect, respond, recover, restore missions/functions as well as components and influencing factors. Published newsletter to HS/CWMD communities to maintain situation awareness. Assessed and recommended changes to policies, doctrine, programs, plans, operations, procedures, technologies. Developed concepts for CWMD strategies. Recommended measures to protect US military bases.

summary: EDUCATION: Political science - PhD in Government from Georgetown Univ. (comparative politics, empirical field research in Germany) EXPERIENCE HILITES: Senior Operations Research Analyst supporting Domestic Nuclear Detection Office (DNDO). Homeland Security: Sr. Ops Research Analyst in support of Domestic Nuclear Detection Office (independent contractor to TASC). Advisor on homeland security and "The Americas" to Defense Threat Reduction Agency (Northrop Grumman, TASC). CISSP (Certified Information Systems Security Professional) - Info assurance/computer security policy & assessments for DOD (SAIC) ORSA (operations research systems analysis): Computer simulation modeling (TACSIM Program, US Army) plus project leadership/system engineering for major combat/Information Warfare model (US Army Studies & Analysis Activity) Political-military studies (US Army Concepts Analysis Agency) (CSIS - Ctr for Strategic and Int'l Studies thinktank) Military tactical/strategic intelligence collection planning, analysis/estimates, incl imagery interpretation/photogrammetry (U.S. Army) SPECIALTIES: Homeland security; Information assurance, special attn to risk management and COOP/DR - Continuity of Ops/disaster recovery; Political-military studies; Intelligence analysis/estimates System engineering project management

title: Political - Military Policy Analyst (think tank "Fellow")
description: Project Manager to lead major studies of pol-mil issues. Organized and coordinated two VIP panel studies and write book length reports for same: (1) Professional Military Education (PME); (2) Military Aid to Inner City Young Adults. Developed detailed research program and budget proposals to obtain funding support for studies.

title: Senior Reports Analyst, Open-Source: Atmospherics Program – Afghanistan (AP-A)
description: Provided information operations intelligence support through data gathering and analysis. Supported complex research and analysis mission requirements through development, documentation, exploitation, and trend analysis of local perceptions relating to Afghanistan governance, USFOR-A, and the Afghan insurgency/terrorism. Provided strategic decision makers with professional advice and assistance in regard to social, religious, economic, political, tribal and security issues through the analysis of events, population perceptions, and trends throughout Afghanistan. Managed the content and delivery of high order analysis products and written reports used to support both strategic and tactical decision making. Record of progressing information output levels through development of original analytical tools and analysis products. Identified information needs by working closely with staff sections, as well as provided rapid response to requests for specific information.

title: Human Terrain Social Scientist: US Army Human Terrain System (HTS)
description: Developed, implemented, and managed ethnographic research and analysis plans in support of commander’s operations. Participated in the Military Decision Making Process by providing and/or coordinating Cultural Preparation of the Environment and Cultural Data Collection Activities. Performed various multi-disciplinary team based human terrain research projects. Designed research plans, carried out field research, analyzed data, and synthesized findings to form alternative courses of action and information products for brigade commander and staff. Coordinated, produced, and disseminated final research products and briefings. Experience analyzing sociological aspects of Afghanistan to include its: culture, religions, ethnicities, tribes, politics, history, and economics.

title: Senior Procurement Manager/Chief of Business Operations
company: Nepal Hospitality Group & Everest Hospitality Group
description: Nepal Hospitality Group (NHG) signed a Hotel Management Agreement with Marriott International, the world’s largest hotel company, to design and construct a Fairfield by Marriott in Kathmandu, Nepal. NHG will serve as owners of the Fairfield. Everest Hospitality Group (EHG) has an agreement in place to design and construct a 5-Star Flagship Marriott and serve as owners of the Hotel. Marriott will take on management of both properties. Responsibilities included: • Overseeing all design and procurement activities with Marriott’s selected partners and NHG chosen suppliers based in India, China, Thailand, the Middle East and Europe. Handled contract negotiations towards product supply agreements demonstrating value towards company budgetary requirements; • As the Manager and Senior Team Leader of a core team of Business Development Managers and Architects, analyzed and interpreted AutoCAD shop drawings as per Marriott specifications and tailored them to NHG requirements to focus on cost without compromising on quality utilizing an approx. $2.2m Interior Design budget; • Participating in discussions with Marriott International Finance Team towards the Hotel Management Agreement for the 5 Star Flagship Marriott Hotel and with design team to finalize interior design; • Participating in discussions and gave presentation to International Finance Corporation (IFC), the private sector development arm of the World Bank to secure loan for the project; • Coordinated discussions with CE Construction Nepal towards final Construction Agreement of the 5 Star Flagship Marriott Hotel; and • Promoted the company’s Corporate Social Responsibility and branding for the event “Kuch Bhi Ho Sakta Hai” by Anupam Kher at the Army Club in Sundhara, Kathmandu.

title: Research Assistant and Technical Proposal Writer
description: EPOS Health Management is an independent worldwide provider of health sector consulting services working globally to improve the quality and accessibility of health services and system. Provided assistance and technical support to the development of a GIZ/EPOS Health Management proposal for a Hospital Management tender with the Government of Nepal and other local partners. Responsibilities include:   • Compiling evidentiary support for Maternal and Child Health (MNCH) indicators using Nepal Demographic Health Sector Survey data;   • Research on MNCH indicators worldwide using minimum requirements for the successful achievement of Millennium Development Goals/targets in Nepal; • Technical writing/editing of proposal (“Health Sector Support Programme/Area: Improving Maternal and Neonatal Care in Nepal”) on the technical concepts, work packages and alternative concepts that will be used as part of tender promotion. • Capacity building on the implementation of the Second National Health Sector Program 2010-2015 (NHSP-II).

title: Consultant, Technical/Proposal Writer
company: South Asian Regional Trade Union Council
description: Operated as a consultant for the South Asian Regional Trade Union Council on the development of a Concept Paper for an ILO funding proposal. The proposal looks at reform of the Nepali foreign labour migration system to the Gulf Cooperation Council in response to the reports of gross violation of International labour laws and Human Rights. Duties include: - Implementation of TU charter work plan from an ILO/SAARC/ITUC/Nepali TUC focal persons workshop. - Research of Nepali and GCC Trade Union networking systems. - Coordination of ILO/SAARC/ITUC/Nepali TUC migration objectives that include understanding of core ILO conventions on international labour standards and foreign migration. - Creation of concept paper and Logical Framework that includes rationale, goals/activities, objectives and output/outcomes utilizing various research tools and methodologies used in concept formulation. - Concept paper will be used as part of proposal to be sent to SAARC and ILO and will be presented at SAARC conferences in the Maldives and New Delhi.

title: Research Assistant
description: Mannion Daniels is an international public health consultancy that work alongside UK's Dept for Int'l Development (DFID) and other donor countries designing, implementing and evaluating public health services in developing countries. As a Research Consultant, I contributed to a major project that aims to implement the three year Somalia Stability Fund (SSF) in Somalia. Responsibilities include: (a) Conducting a participatory conflict and needs appraisal in Kismayo. (b) Formulating a conflict profile for Kismayo, identifying drivers and triggers of local conflict and economic, political, socio-cultural context and emerging issues (c) Conducting a stakeholder analysis to understand the dynamics and overlapping interests of local actors in Kismayo (d) Identifying opportunities and potential strategies for initiating dialogue in Kismayo amongst various groups.

title: Associate/Analyst
description: Maintain day-to-day relationships with the country's largest Commercial brokerage firms. Main functions including research and analysis expertise of multi-million dollar value Institutional Sales Comparables from scouting to acquisition as well as capturing critical leasing data allowing company clients to benchmark their rates and deals as well as reflect on the state of the commercial real estate market. Research Methods include filtering through Deeds and Mortgages, Securities and Exchange Commission 8K and 10K filings, Tax collection and assessments, county clerks and websites, and Costar Group's CRM database. Accomplishments include: - Portfolio and client management that require high levels of adaptivity and flexibility. - Quickly rose to within the top 5% of research analysts based on quality and quantity of research. -Cooperated in the company's transition and onboarding process following Loopnet acquisition. - Led the company's Northern New Jersey team for consecutive quarters.

title: Intern, Department of International Cooperation, Assistance and Development (ICA)
description: The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) is the implementing body of the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC or Convention). The OPCW is given the mandate to achieve the object and purpose of the Convention, to ensure the implementation of its provisions, including those for international verification of compliance with it, and to provide a forum for consultation and cooperation among States Parties. The organisation won the 2013 Nobel Peace Prize for its continued efforts to locate, verify and destroy Syria's chemical weapons stockpiles. My responsibilities as an intern included: - Preparing draft correspondence between the organisation and member states parties. - Coordinated between ICA, legal and the media department for the OPCW summer events calendar. - Interviewed members taking part in seminar at the "TMC Asser Institut". - Provided the organisation with feedback on how to effectively expand their internship programme.

summary: Offering over 18 years of superior performance with an emphasis in Operations and Intelligence (O&I) experience combing military (18Z, 18F, 18C and 11B), and civilian experience with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers as a Civil Engineering Technician working directly with testing and evaluating measures for U.S. Army personnel Force Protection Survivability measures. Demonstrated superior performance in crisis management while acting as the Special Operations Task Force - East (SOTF-E) Operations Center (OPCEN) Senior Enlisted representative during 2- 6 month deployments to OEF. Orchestrated and oversaw multiple Special Forces Level 1 and 2 CONOPS providing all necessary support and coordination with higher headquarters, Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force – Afghanistan (CJSOTF-A) for successful completion. Qualifications: Special Forces Qualification Course - 18C, 18F and 18Z Ranger School - 11B4V Airborne, Jumpmaster HALO Unit Assignments: HQ 2nd BN 20th SFG(A) C/2/20th SFG(A) USAJFKSWC- Robin Sage Instructor B/3/5th SFG(A) Company C, 2nd BN 75th Ranger Regiment

title: Operations Integrator/Intelligence Analyst
description: Operations Subject Matter Expert, NAI-CLT, Regional Commands (RC) South, Southwest and East. Operations Lead and Intelligence Analyst in Fob Ghazni, Ghazni Province, RC-East COIC- Afghanistan while assigned to NATO Partnered Polish Task Force. While assigned to Polish Unit, recommend and approved awarding of the Polish equivalent of a US Army Bronze Star authorized only by Polish Commanding General of Military services. Serves as the subject matter expert of operations in support of JIEDDO Counter-IED (C-IED) in Afghanistan. Performs the senior operations advisor on an operations/intelligence analytical team of military and/or DoD civilian analysts in support of the CJ2 analytical requirements. Responsible for coordination of operational and strategic level research and development products in support of US objectives. These products include counter-terrorism, Human Intelligence (HUMINT), Signal Intelligence (SIGINT), counterintelligence, Special Programs Management & Integration, Afghanistan and South West Asia regional issues, political/military analysis and support to targeting of insurgent forces.

summary: Offering over 18 years of superior performance with an emphasis in Operations and Intelligence (O&I) experience combing military (18Z, 18F, 18C and 11B), and civilian experience with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers as a Civil Engineering Technician working directly with testing and evaluating measures for U.S. Army personnel Force Protection Survivability measures. Demonstrated superior performance in crisis management while acting as the Special Operations Task Force - East (SOTF-E) Operations Center (OPCEN) Senior Enlisted representative during 2- 6 month deployments to OEF. Orchestrated and oversaw multiple Special Forces Level 1 and 2 CONOPS providing all necessary support and coordination with higher headquarters, Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force – Afghanistan (CJSOTF-A) for successful completion. Qualifications: Special Forces Qualification Course - 18C, 18F and 18Z Ranger School - 11B4V Airborne, Jumpmaster HALO Unit Assignments: HQ 2nd BN 20th SFG(A) C/2/20th SFG(A) USAJFKSWC- Robin Sage Instructor B/3/5th SFG(A) Company C, 2nd BN 75th Ranger Regiment

title: Chief of Research
description: Supervises approximately 12 faculty and research staff to conduct research in national security and international relations for the leadership of the U.S. Air Force and the Department of Defense. Manages the contract research budget for Air University -- a Level V doctoral degree-granting university specializing in national security, public policy and international relations. Acts, as needed, as adjunct professor at the Air War College, Air Command and Staff College and Squadron Officer College. Briefly served as interim Deputy Director and Dean during transition period between directors and key personnal in 2012-2013.

summary: Strategic Planning at any organizational level. Published author on long-range strategic planning. Able to lead organizations on a path of self-discovery as to how the future will change its ability to function in the years ahead. Television Weather Anchor/Meteorologist. Achieved overall Nielsen and Arbitron ratings in the upper 30s with share ratings in the low 50s as Chief Meteorologist for WISC-TV -- top 100 market. Pioneered use of on-air picture in teleprompter enabling meteorologists to appear more comfortable on-camera. Military analyst. Proficient in all econometric means of analysis and my directorship of research centers has brought me into contact with virtually every system DOD uses today. 27 years of experience analyzing and developing concepts of operations across four continents provides me the background to offer analytical commentary or advice on the implications and outcomes of impending military operations. Specialties: Leadership, Strategic Planning, Meterology, Political Science, Teaching, Lecturing, Analytical or Applied Research

title: Colonel (retired)
description: Served for over 28 years on active duty as flight instructor in F-111 aircraft; chief administrator for several organizations up to 4000 persons in size; Chief, Leadership Branch for the Air Force's primary leadership school for all members of its officer corps; Chief of Strategic Planning for all Air Force Special Forces, managing a $9 billion modernization portfolio. Held numerous supervisory and leadership positions within fighter and special operations as well as in the Air Force's university system. Served as a flight instructor in the T-37, T-43, and F-111 aircraft and have logged combat time in the AC-130 gunship. I have lectured and taught seminars, both at the undergraduate and gratudate levels at the Senior Non-Commissioned Officer Academy, the Squadron Officer College, Air Command and Staff College, and the Air War College.

title: Air Force Institute of Technology Liaison; Associate Professor, Aerospace Studies
description: Supervised all officers attending Air Force-directed Education at the UW. Discovered and resolved housing and medical benefits issues that had been left to atrophy for 10 years, putting all junior personnel below the poverty line and without access to health care. Fixed both in 18 months; moved our non-commissioned officers out of the housing projects, and ensured they were paid wages above the poverty line. Completed PhD in Political Science in 2 years 9 months, breaking the departmental record. Studied all analytical methods to include basic and advanced statistics, maximum likelihood, qualitative methods, fuzzy set logic, and auto-regressive integrated moving-average time-series modeling. Analytically trainind in all tools.

title: Intelligence Analyst
description: Produce intelligence products using geospatial analysis and analysis of enemy networks and operating environment for units conducting training exercises. Transform the real operating environment in Afghanistan or other region into a realistic training scenario on a training base. Analyze data using ArcGIS and Analyst Notebook to visualize event patterns and social networks. Perform information retrieval using DCGS-A, CIDNE, and other intelligence databases to compile data sets for use in home station training environments. Integrate opposing force role players into enemy networks and enroll into biometrics. Populate DCGS-A with transformed data integrated with exercise. Mentor intelligence staff during training and serve as higher headquarters S2/G2. Represent TBOC at various exercise planning conferences and provide operating environment overview and develop storylines to support Commander's training objectives. Deploy as member of Exercise White Cell during exercise to dynamically script storyline events to facilitate training objectives, replicate reach back capability through intelligence production, quality check exercise data for ingestion into Army Battle Command Systems such as DCGS-A. Produced real world threat trend analysis and operating environment intelligence reports for units preparing to deploy to Afghanistan or Iraq. Received Certificate of Recognition from TBOC for developing exercise products for the 504th BfSB at FT Hood, TX.

summary: Over twenty years experience as an intelligence officer in the Army, National Guard and Reserve. Currently training intelligence staffs and supporting training exercises with realistic intelligence scenarios using geospatial tools. Numerous assignments from Battalion S2, Deputy Division G2, Army Air & Missile Defense Command G2 and Task Force Phoenix J2 in Afghanistan. In depth experience building exercise storylines to support commander’s objectives. Rigorous experience with Military Support to Civilian Authorities supporting state agencies for natural disasters and homeland defense including Hurricane Hugo. Built intelligence team for Army Air and Missile Defense headquarters that was successful at tactical and operational level and built architectures for new missile defense units. Extensive experience in Military Decision Making Process, intelligence briefings and producing intelligence products to support the Commander’s objectives.

title: Deputy G2, Intelligence Officer
description: Ensured that mobilizing Reserve Component forces in the Eastern United States received the required intelligence training to accomplish their wartime missions. Coordinated with First Army, leveraged national assets, enabled nine subordinate Brigade Intelligence Sections and captured the experience of deployed intelligence sections to provide training that is current and relevant to their mission requirements. Provided intelligence products to the Division Commander and staff. Supported brigades by filtering intelligence from Iraq and Afghanistan that pertained to mobilizing units to allow training against current enemy tactics. Provided Division Staff with Physical Security, Personnel Security, Operations Security and Information Security support. Provided language training to mobilizing reserve units. Mentored the intelligence training for Task Force Phoenix 8 (mentoring the Afghan Army and Police). Trained and mentored 13 Intelligence staffs for Afghanistan Provincial Reconstruction Teams 2008.

summary: Over twenty years experience as an intelligence officer in the Army, National Guard and Reserve. Currently training intelligence staffs and supporting training exercises with realistic intelligence scenarios using geospatial tools. Numerous assignments from Battalion S2, Deputy Division G2, Army Air & Missile Defense Command G2 and Task Force Phoenix J2 in Afghanistan. In depth experience building exercise storylines to support commander’s objectives. Rigorous experience with Military Support to Civilian Authorities supporting state agencies for natural disasters and homeland defense including Hurricane Hugo. Built intelligence team for Army Air and Missile Defense headquarters that was successful at tactical and operational level and built architectures for new missile defense units. Extensive experience in Military Decision Making Process, intelligence briefings and producing intelligence products to support the Commander’s objectives.

title: J2
description: Supervised a staff of over a hundred intelligence analysts and specialists from Army, Air Force, Navy, Marines, active and reserve components distributed throughout Afghanistan. Staffs worked in cooperation with Afghan intelligence and coalition partners to produce intelligence products for regional commanders. Established a server and a signals intelligence cell to support commander’s requirements. Built a counterintelligence team and operations management team to support force protection needs that is integrated with theater human intelligence assets. This team produced actionable intelligence that led to the disruption of several improvised explosive device facilitators. Supported teams mentoring Afghan intelligence soldiers. Gave a presentation by request at the National Ground Intelligence Center Afghan Conference on the status of the Afghan National Security Forces. Managed almost 1,000 local national linguists to support task force operations. Established biometric scanning at entry control points.

title: Senior Military Analyst
description: Built Enterprise architecture for Ground-based Midcourse Defense Brigade & Battalion which are Army and National Guard units that man and operate the national ballistic missile defense system. Researched operations and interviewed dozens of soldiers and contractors on site in Colorado and Ft Greely, AK then incorporated their input to build an accurate and current operations architecture. Developed operations architecture for the Forward Based X-Band Radar Detachments.

title: Assistant Chief of Staff for Intelligence (G2)
description: Conducted Theater Missile Defense Intelligence Preparation of the Battle-space (TMD IPB) as the US Army Air and Missile Defense Command Intelligence Officer during the US-Russian Federation joint missile defense exercise at FT Bliss, 2006. Coordinated planning with Joint Task Force operations and intelligence and with Russian counterparts. Supervised Army Forces component white cell at exercise Austere Challenge 2006. Trained and integrated intelligence section to form an intelligence section for Exercise Juniper Cobra 05 in Israel that integrated US and Israeli intelligence preparations. Conducted Theater Missile Defense Intelligence for Joint Forces Command Exercise at Shaw AFB to include air and cruise missile threat. Supervised joint cruise missile and tactical ballistic missile operations with Air Force intelligence to support joint integrated air defense.

title: Nursery and Tree Improvement Section Chief & Forester
description: Supervised statewide seed production facilities and nurseries producing 10-20 million seedlings per year. Managed statewide staff of ten personnel, budget, multiple facilities, operations and customer sales and distribution. Directed field research projects, published results and incorporated findings into operational program. Supervised forest tree genetics program bringing new program into production to meet all of South Carolina’s forest tree seed needs while developing the next generation of superior trees to continue the process of improvement. Designed and built new state of the art tree seed processing facility.

title: Deputy Intelligence Officer (G2)
description: Successfully completed certification of Intelligence section for missile defense mission. Intelligence section was the most highly rated section of the command. Arranged for intelligence section to train CENTAF intelligence section on Generic Area Limitation of the Environment (GALE) system. During US -Korean exercise served as G2 battle captain of a joint Tactical Ballistic Missile cell successfully integrating personnel from five different units and a national agency. Supervised system operators, collection, targeting, conducted command briefings, synchronization board briefings, served as primary G2 planner. Our intelligence products were used throughout the Korean Theater winning our unit much acclaim and aiding in the unit’s final certification.

title: Security and Intelligence Officer
description: Developed a Forest Fire Operations Plan and a Drought Operations Plan for National Guard support to civilian authorities. Provided weather, intelligence and coordination to deployed units and state headquarters during Hurricanes Dennis and Floyd and an upstate ice storm. As a Force Protection Level I briefer conducted numerous threat and force protection briefings to units deploying overseas. Assisted with security issues at state headquarters after 9-11 attack.

summary: Over twenty years experience as an intelligence officer in the Army, National Guard and Reserve. Currently training intelligence staffs and supporting training exercises with realistic intelligence scenarios using geospatial tools. Numerous assignments from Battalion S2, Deputy Division G2, Army Air & Missile Defense Command G2 and Task Force Phoenix J2 in Afghanistan. In depth experience building exercise storylines to support commander’s objectives. Rigorous experience with Military Support to Civilian Authorities supporting state agencies for natural disasters and homeland defense including Hurricane Hugo. Built intelligence team for Army Air and Missile Defense headquarters that was successful at tactical and operational level and built architectures for new missile defense units. Extensive experience in Military Decision Making Process, intelligence briefings and producing intelligence products to support the Commander’s objectives.

title: US Antarctic Program Instrument Technician
description: • Provided scientific and instrumentation support for National Science Foundation grantees at Palmer Station, a US Antarctic Program field station. • Oversaw the maintenance and repair of a diverse array of scientific instrumentation on station, including spectrophotometers, liquid scintillation analyzers, and deionized water systems. Troubleshot developing instrumentation issues, diagnosed equipment problems, and identified solutions in a limited resource environment. • Managed grantees’ needs and the finite resources of a remote field station by systematically allocating instrumentation, sourcing available alternatives when necessary, and helping arrange equipment logistics. • Collaborated intra- and inter-departmentally to organize projects, procure supplies, and standardize operating procedures. Liaised between grantees and US Antarctic Support Contract office to communicate project needs, potential problems, and future improvements. • Expanded the station’s instrument reference knowledge by documenting new information and procedures in a written and illustrated series of instrument manuals and instrument repair histories. • Participated in community safety as a member of fire-fighting team and ocean search and rescue team.

title: Co-founder
description: • Built a custom clothing design retail platform from the ground up before selling share to business partner. • Managed design process including developing concepts, securing suppliers, and assessing final product quality. • Built relationships with approximately twenty new clients and achieved break-even by month three. • Conceptualized company brand and led website design and creation process. Developed content for website including company mission statement, product descriptions, and company order policies. • Increased revenues by building a social media presence on Pintrest, Facebook, and Twitter to engage with potential clients. Managed marketing strategy by researching potential sales channels, writing press releases, and attracting press from the media. • Provided personalized customer service in addition to designing, furnishing, and maintaining retail space. • Maintained financial records and a strict budget by consistently managing competing priorities and analyzing the ROI of past spending to inform future financial decisions, and indicate the viability of the business model.

title: Assistant Scientist
description: • Managed laboratory watches aboard a research/sailing school vessel and guided undergraduate students in executing a research project. • Managed constant challenge of maintaining strict shipboard safety, ensuring students were learning, and running the lab efficiently. Managed up to 20 students and two crewmembers on each voyage. • Taught students through lecture and in the laboratory about oceanographic concepts. Mentored students on scientific writing and processes, and fine tuned interpersonal skills by carefully delegating responsibility and providing feedback when appropriate. • Led data collection and management process thereby teaching students about the value of minute details on both small-scale activities like titration, and large-scale operations such as moving hundreds of pounds of instrumentation via a hydro winch. • Managed all lab gear and equipment including delegating preventative maintenance, providing troubleshooting, and diagnosing problems, and collaborated with the staff on shore to indentify solutions. • Promoted from 3rd to 2nd scientist within six months based on demonstrated ability to manage multiple projects and to rapidly improve weaknesses through self-directed learning.

title: Compost Ourtreach Coordinator
description: The purpose of the program is to “close the loop” on a portion of the waste energy originating in the food system. Our community includes 1700 farms, most of them raising food. With curbside food and yard waste collection and composting facilities in the County, there is the opportunity to expand use of compost on farms. This program will conduct the applied research needed to validate use of compost on important local crops and create compost demonstration sites at up to 27 farms. Demand will be stimulated and a sustainable market created for returning waste food energy to local farms.

title: Technical Assistant
description: While employed at the Crops and Soils department of the WSU Research Extension in Puyallup I directly participated in: • Investigations into the decomposition of common antibiotics in compost • Developing Organic farming system rotations with the use of livestock • Investigating alternative solutions for reducing microbial activity in Organic farming produce and poultry • Various methods of monitoring soil structure and chemistry to maximize biomass production and ecosystem health. Additionally, I personally facilitated the deployment and maintenance of 100 plus remotes sensors used to monitor soil temperature, matric water potential, and light infiltration resulting in more than 50,000 unique events. This data was used to quantify the effectiveness of various Organic cover crop rotations and tillage methods.

summary: Executive, strategist, policy analyst, planner, and servant leader who creates positive value by building lean teams and developing subordinates. Experienced with using data analysis to drive increase profits, efficiency, and effectiveness. Negotiating support from stakeholders, improving teamwork, capitalizing on diverse perspectives, and building effective relationships in support of international security, peace, humanitarian assistance, and capacity development are core competencies. Facilitated interagency coordination and intelligence fusion in support of National Security policy. Satisfied customers lead to business growth.

title: Deputy Chief
description: • Revised and automated operations to achieve 100% accountability of activated Army Reserve Component forces. • Managed activities and processes which mobilized 350,000 U.S. citizen soldiers. • Built strong relationships with senior Army and Department of Defense decision makers. • Improved and automated staff workflows and approval processes increasing efficiency and improving process timelines by more than 85%. • Prepared Chief of Staff and Secretary of the Army for Congressional testimony. • Hand-picked to lead Army team tasked with planning improvement of complex Army Reserve Component mobilization processes and policies affecting 574,000 personnel.

summary: Executive, strategist, policy analyst, planner, and servant leader who creates positive value by building lean teams and developing subordinates. Experienced with using data analysis to drive increase profits, efficiency, and effectiveness. Negotiating support from stakeholders, improving teamwork, capitalizing on diverse perspectives, and building effective relationships in support of international security, peace, humanitarian assistance, and capacity development are core competencies. Facilitated interagency coordination and intelligence fusion in support of National Security policy. Satisfied customers lead to business growth.

summary: • Over 20 years experience as a leader, manager, instructor and technician. Enlisted as a Surface Sonar Technican in 1993 and achieved the rank of Chief Petty Officer in 2002. Selected for the Limited Duty Officer program (Surface Electronics) and commissioned in 2003. • Serves as an officer technical manager in the field of non-nuclear electronics. • Plans, coordinates, directs, and manages the installation, operation, and maintenance of all non-nuclear electronic systems installed in units of the surface force. • Conducts operational evaluations of new installations and modifications to existing systems. • Provides operational and technical input to the research and development community for consideration in the design and testing of electronic systems or components. • Prepares and distributes operator training courses and operation guidance for electronic systems. • Plans, schedules, and conducts training for electronics personnel. • Writes reports, prepares budgets, and provides technical advice about electronic systems. • Accounts for classified equipment, material and documents utilized.

title: C5ISR Modernization Policy (C5IMP) Manager
description: Represents the Fleet Commander as final approval authority for the modernization and installation of all Command & Control, Communications, Computers, Combat Systems & Intelligence (C5I) systems aboard Pacific Fleet ships and submarines. • Administers Commander U.S. Fleet Forces Command (CUSFFC) and Commander U.S. Pacific Fleet (CPF) Joint C5I modernization policy. • Coordinates with Military and Civilian program managers to plan baseline configurations and affect changes to support installing non-nuclear C5I systems and equipment on ships and submarines. Stakeholders include: o Program Executive Office (PEO) for C4I, o PEO for Integrated Warfare Systems (IWS), o PEO for Enterprise Information Systems (EIS), o PEO for Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) o Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA), o Naval Air Systems Command (NAVAIR), o Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command (SPAWAR), o Fleet staffs for Commander Third and Seventh Fleets (C3F) (C7F) and o Four Type Commanders (TYCOM) Commander Naval Surface Forces, Commander Submarine Forces, Commander Naval Air Forces and Commander Navy Information Dominance Forces. • Evaluates and analyzes modernization plans and associated risk for non-mature exceptions for installation of C5I systems for Pacific Fleet ships and submarines. • Leads process improvement teams to develop and implement policy and process changes for efficiencies and harvest financial savings while modernizing the fleet.

title: Electronic Materials Officer
description: Responsible for the readiness of all assigned electronic equipment, the administration of the electronic material function, and the repair of all shipboard electronic equipment. • Managed and supervised the electronics preventive maintenance program. • Administered maintenance and allowance of shipboard electronic equipment. • Interpreted and carried out systems commands or manufacturers' instructions for equipment, establishing maintenance standards and ensuring readiness. • Diagnosed causes of malfunctions and directed repair, modification, alteration and installation of equipment. • Directed requisitioning of spare parts and gear. • Directed preparation and submittal of work requests, reports and informative data required for tender/yard overhaul of electronic equipment. • Established and maintained a reporting and record system following with current instructions on the material status of all electronic equipment, including authorized equipment changes, repairs, and expenditure of repair funds. • Assisted and advised operating personnel, as requested by cognizant officers, in the proper operational procedures and characteristics of electronic equipment, including performance capabilities and limitations.

summary: • Over 20 years experience as a leader, manager, instructor and technician. Enlisted as a Surface Sonar Technican in 1993 and achieved the rank of Chief Petty Officer in 2002. Selected for the Limited Duty Officer program (Surface Electronics) and commissioned in 2003. • Serves as an officer technical manager in the field of non-nuclear electronics. • Plans, coordinates, directs, and manages the installation, operation, and maintenance of all non-nuclear electronic systems installed in units of the surface force. • Conducts operational evaluations of new installations and modifications to existing systems. • Provides operational and technical input to the research and development community for consideration in the design and testing of electronic systems or components. • Prepares and distributes operator training courses and operation guidance for electronic systems. • Plans, schedules, and conducts training for electronics personnel. • Writes reports, prepares budgets, and provides technical advice about electronic systems. • Accounts for classified equipment, material and documents utilized.

title: Ground Electronics Maintenance Officer/ Asst Operations Officer/ Installation Training Officer
description: • Managed installation, maintenance and repair of electronic equipment and systems. • Managed maintenance of equipment and work of shops engaged in repair of landing and navigation aids. • Implemented schedules for repairs or services. • Inspected and ensured readiness of equipment. • Directed maintenance of adequate stocks of spare parts, accounting for classified equipment utilized. • Coordinated requests for technical assistance. • Served as the Installations Training Team Coordinator to coordinate and organize the preparation for installation training • Established and assessed the Installation's integrated training, readiness and exercise program. • Developed and promulgated action plans (lessons learned) to correct deficiencies and gaps. • Coordinated training exercises. • Developed requirements, plans, exercises and strategies for ashore training. • Oversaw individual workforce training and education

title: Sonar Technician
description: Enlisted in the United States Navy in July 1993. Served as a Sonar Technician on USS Kitty Hawk (CV 63) and USS Mobile Bay (CG 53). Achieved the rank of Chief Petty Officer (E-7) In September 2002. Specific duties and responsibilities: • Completed maintenance reports; trained and supervised personnel in the operation of equipment. • Supervised maintenance and repair of sonar equipment; Prepared weekly maintenance schedules. • Supervised training of personnel in operation, maintenance, and repair of equipment. • Administered a long-range maintenance program; prepared quarterly maintenance schedules. • Operated, troubleshot, repaired, and maintained shipboard sonar and weapons control systems. • Familiar with oceanographic aspects such as wave propagation in a fluid medium. • Performed operational tests and makes external adjustments on equipment. • Used schematic and wiring/circuitry diagrams; Completed maintenance data forms. • Installed minor modifications to electronic sonar equipment. • Inventoried tools, portable test equipment, and installed equipment.
headquarters:
2000 Navy Pentagon

Washington,
DC

summary: • Over 20 years experience as a leader, manager, instructor and technician. Enlisted as a Surface Sonar Technican in 1993 and achieved the rank of Chief Petty Officer in 2002. Selected for the Limited Duty Officer program (Surface Electronics) and commissioned in 2003. • Serves as an officer technical manager in the field of non-nuclear electronics. • Plans, coordinates, directs, and manages the installation, operation, and maintenance of all non-nuclear electronic systems installed in units of the surface force. • Conducts operational evaluations of new installations and modifications to existing systems. • Provides operational and technical input to the research and development community for consideration in the design and testing of electronic systems or components. • Prepares and distributes operator training courses and operation guidance for electronic systems. • Plans, schedules, and conducts training for electronics personnel. • Writes reports, prepares budgets, and provides technical advice about electronic systems. • Accounts for classified equipment, material and documents utilized.

title: Team Lead, EHRC "Explosive Hazard Reduction Course"
description: Provide Partner Nation Forces w/ Special Operations Forces Training in order to conduct IED mitigation and site exploitation. Provide instruction on current domestic and international insurgent threats, tactics and procedures to include; IED threats on explosive hazards; homemade explosive, and the planning process to respond to an IED/Surface Ordnance scene/incident in both a permissive and non-permissive environments. Deliver group-paced instruction on current C-IED tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTP), EOD related tools, improvised/homemade C-IED tools, to include explosive demolition and the application of explosives for explosive hazard reduction. Preparation and facilitation of practical hands-on training with specialized training devices, detection and identification equipment/methods and the theory and application of electronic countermeasures. Perform set-up and management of IED/UXO practical exercises for student scenario based training. Evaluate response procedures, to include command and control and provide advice/mentorship as required. Maintain knowledge base as a subject matter expert (SME) in assigned course content and perform as SOF SME Team Lead for input relative to training team security during MTT missions. Conducting IED research using web and web-based tools such as CIDNE, TIGR, Palantir, ACME, WEAT, COIC-A, periodicals, journals, open source Internet, etc. to identify and interpret evolving threats and innovations in TTP within the C-IED and Counter-Terrorism communities.

title: Intell
description: I currently conduct intelligence missions such as screening Locally Employed Personnel, patrol debriefings, and intelligence liaison with military units and national level agencies. I conduct biometrics enrollments in order to build biometrics database and identify individuals on the Biometrics Enabled Watch List (BEWL) who pose a threat to International Security Assistance Forces. I conduct searches of intelligence databases and perform analysis of biometrics enrollment history and BEWL to identify persons of interest for further Counterintelligence screening. I also provide support to Operational Security/Threat Awareness and Reporting (formerly SAEDA) programs and administer Preliminary Creditability Assessment Screening System (PCASS) examinations to thwart “Insider Attacks”. I report findings in a clear, logical, impartial, and concise report.

description: I conducted asymmetric unconventional warfare, multi-intelligence, threat analysis and fusion of insurgent/criminal networks associated with Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs). I provided commanders and decision makers with the intelligence needed to conduct and plan full-spectrum operations and implement counter insurgency (COIN) strategy in order to enhance Afghanistan's stability.

title: Operations Manager
description: I tracked and monitored all new Logistical Training Team (LLT) personnel from CONUS Replacement Center to Kuwait. I provided progress reports on all incoming personnel from Kuwait to Afghanistan. I provided transportation from airfield, completed their in-processing, provided initial in-country briefings along with PM and A-PM, and scheduled air movement of all LTT trainers to their final work sites. I maintained manning rosters on all individuals assigned to the program and provide updates to the LTT program manager. I monitored the progress on numerous nine person teams throughout the theater of operations. I managed team leads to provide weekly personnel and logistic status reports on their respective Afghan Commando companies.

title: Tactical Exploitation Trainer/Tactical Advisor
description: I conducted pre and post blast sensitive site exploitations. I assisted in the collection of forensics and biometric evidence at blast sites. I worked with ground force commander to ensure site security, providing a safe working environment for Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) personnel to operate. I ensured EOD and Counter Improvised Explosive Device (CIED) team members were proficient in the use of individual weapons, weapon systems not organic to team, and infantry mounted and dismounted operations and kept team members abreast of current insurgent tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs). I concurrently worked with Afghanistan National Security Forces in compliance with evidence based and COIN operations in order to ensure subsequent prosecution of IED facilitators and emplacers.

title: Tactical Lead
description: I conducted asymmetric, multi-intelligence threat analysis and fusion of insurgent and criminal networks intelligence in support of the Joint Improvised Explosive Device Defeat Organization (JIEDDO) attack the network mission. I directly participated in Time Sensitive Targeting, assisted in ground Assault Force missions in tactical/ sensitive site exploitation operations, crime scene investigations, evidence collection/ exploitation, and pre/ post blast site exploitation of improvised explosive device (IED) events to uncover and target the operational, financial and social networks of insurgent groups. I am knowledgeable of the intelligence cycle and the Fix, Find, Finish, Exploit, Analyze and Disseminate (F3EAD) targeting method.

title: Research Manager/ Analyst
description: I conducted research and analysis of tribal dynamics, counterinsurgency, atmospherics for intelligence reporting to assist military units in conducting non-lethal operations by allowing the unit to better dialogue with the population, to understand the population’s political, economic and social needs, and to understand the history of particular tribes and social groups in their area of operations. Efforts helped develop more effective courses of actions, such as providing security, essential services, and economic development opportunities to the civilian population in order to encourage the civilian population to support the host nation government and reduce their support for insurgent groups. I completed Human Terrain Systems training which included area-specific orientation training (Iraq regional studies); field research methods and techniques; military staff planning/ decision making procedures; information operations; intelligence fusion and analysis; COIN operations; introduction to anthropology; refresher training on Analyst Notebook and MAP-HT Toolkit use; and combat lifesaver training.

title: Firearms Instructor
description: I provided platform instruction and practical application pertaining to combat shooting techniques involving 9mm pistols of different variants and M4 carbine to Navy EOD personnel preparing to deploy to Iraq and Afghanistan. I provided hands on training during range instruction and presented demonstrations involving pistol and M4 carbine shooting applications during day light hours and times of limited visibility. I provided weapons familiarization to include 50 cal heavy machine-gun, M60 machine-gun in various configurations, M203 40mm grenade launcher. I taught other instruction to include patrolling, techniques in urban areas, CQB, vehicle egress, immediate action drills during vehicle convoy and foot patrols.

title: Security Force Team Leader
description: January 2004 – June 2006 Cochise Consulting INC; Security Force Team Leader - Iraq I was overall responsible for the welfare and safety of USAE personnel while they conduct the destruction of Iraqi munitions throughout Iraq. Planned, scheduled, and conducted training of team members to remain proficient in their duties as Force Protection Officers to include weapons training, base security, and personal security. I planned, organized and conducted convoy missions throughout the Iraq Theater. I was responsible for receiving, analyzing, and disseminating time-sensitive threat intelligence to team members. I conducted intelligence briefings, site assessments, and route reconnaissance for mission planning.

title: Northern Regional Logistic Manager
description: I was responsible for the logistical support for Northern Iraq covering thousands of square miles in support of Titan Corporation and subcontractor employees deployed in support of the United States Army’s mission for “Operation Iraqi Freedom”. I provided weekly logistical support to four Titan Corporation remote sites and one regional headquarters site, consisting of hundreds of personnel performing critical support for the United States Army. I integrated quality management techniques in processing requests, prioritizing the requirements, and accounting for equipment. I analyzed and filled all mission essential requests in a timely manner and provided ongoing assessments of the entire regional sites to meet future needs. I additionally provided daily backup mission critical support to Titan and SOSi regional and local site managers.

title: Force Protection Officer
description: I was responsible for providing Security, Force Protection, and Law Enforcement support for the United States Army, Camp Doha, Kuwait. I performed individual basic combat tactics and techniques unique to military service. I ensured proper disposition of cases and violator(s) in accordance with the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ), Federal Laws and Military Regulations. I maintained a working relationship with Host Nation Civilians and Military Counterparts. I performed duties as a fire team member during attacks, defense and counter terrorist operations, and provided in-transit security for military personnel, supplies and equipment. My duties assisted Security Force in conducting operations without incident during threat condition Delta from January to May 2003.
